metadata.title: South Africa accuses 6 of massive rhino horn trafficking scheme involving nearly 1,000 horns

left: Six suspects have been arrested by the Directorate for Priority Crime Investigation in relation to a wildlife trafficking syndicate involving over 900 rhino horns due to a seven-year investigation.
The suspects face multiple charges, including fraud, theft, and contravention of the National Environmental Management: Biodiversity Act.
The fraudulent permit scheme allowed for the illegal trade of rhino horns to Southeast Asia, with an estimated 964 horns worth millions of rands involved.

Forestry, Fisheries and Environment Minister Dion George called the arrests a significant victory in combating international wildlife crime and emphasized South Africa's commitment to protect its natural heritage.
center: John Hume, 83, was arrested alongside five others for an alleged rhino horn trafficking scheme involving 964 horns worth millions of rands destined for illegal markets in Southeast Asia.

It is alleged that between 2017 and 2024, the accused operated an international rhino horn trafficking syndicate and defrauded the Department of Forestry, Fisheries, and the Environment by obtaining permits to trade rhino horn locally while intending to channel the horns into illegal international markets.
South Africa Charges Ex-Rhino Rancher John Hume Over Alleged 964-Horn Trafficking Scheme.
right: Six people were arrested in Pretoria for allegedly trafficking over 900 rhino horns using fraudulent permits.
The investigation, which began in 2017, revealed a scheme defrauding the Department of Forestry, Fisheries, and Environment to traffic rhino horns internationally.
The suspects face multiple charges, including fraud, theft, and violations of the National Environmental Management Biodiversity Act.
Rhino horns cannot be sold to non-South African citizens due to an international ban on their export.
